Line 108: Line 108:
In spite of speculation to the contrary, President Mubarak and his son both denied the possibility of any inheritance of power in Egypt. In early 2006 Gamal Mubarak declared repeatedly that he had no aspiration to succeed his father, but that he would maintain his position in the NDP as deputy secretary general, a post he holds in addition to heading the party's policy committee.<ref>[http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/egypt/?id=16096 ]{{dead link|date=March 2011}}</ref>
In spite of speculation to the contrary, President Mubarak and his son both denied the possibility of any inheritance of power in Egypt. In early 2006 Gamal Mubarak declared repeatedly that he had no aspiration to succeed his father, but that he would maintain his position in the NDP as deputy secretary general, a post he holds in addition to heading the party's policy committee.<ref>[http://www.middle-east-online.com/english/egypt/?id=16096 ]{{dead link|date=March 2011}}</ref>
â
In September 2004 several political groups (most are unofficial), on both the left and the right, announced their sharp opposition to the inheritance of power. They demanded political change and asked for a fair election with more than one candidate.<ref>http://mengos.net/events/04newsevents/egypt/september/9september04.htm</ref>
+
In September 2004 several political groups (most are unofficial), on both the left and the right, announced their sharp opposition to the inheritance of power. They demanded political change and asked for a fair election with more than one candidate.<ref>[http://mengos.net/events/04newsevents/egypt/september/9september04.htm ]{{dead link|date=April 2011}}</ref>
After the JanuaryâFebruary 2011 protest, Gamal Mubarak stated that he would not be running for the presidency in the 2011 elections.<ref>{{cite news|last=BBC|title=Egypt unrest: Anti-Mubarak protesters fight back|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12357891|newspaper=British Broadcasting Company|date=February 3, 2011}}</ref>
After the JanuaryâFebruary 2011 protest, Gamal Mubarak stated that he would not be running for the presidency in the 2011 elections.<ref>{{cite news|last=BBC|title=Egypt unrest: Anti-Mubarak protesters fight back|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12357891|newspaper=British Broadcasting Company|date=February 3, 2011}}</ref>
Line 287: Line 287:
On 27 January, Mansoura was dubbed a "War Zone". On 28 January, 13 were reported dead in violent clashes. On 9 February, 18 more protesters had died.
On 27 January, Mansoura was dubbed a "War Zone". On 28 January, 13 were reported dead in violent clashes. On 9 February, 18 more protesters had died.
â
On 3 February, 4,000 protesters went to the streets to call for Mubarak's departure.<ref>http://af.reuters.com/article/tunisiaNews/idAFLDE71014Z20110203?pageNumber=3&virtualBrandChannel=0</ref>
+
On 3 February, 4,000 protesters went to the streets to call for Mubarak's departure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/tunisiaNews/idAFLDE71014Z20110203?pageNumber=3&virtualBrandChannel=0 |title=TIMELINE-Protests in Egypt | News by Country | Reuters |publisher=Af.reuters.com |date=2011-02-03 |accessdate=2011-04-13}}</ref>

Line 301: Line 301:
[[Bedouins]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]] fought security forces for several weeks.<ref>{{cite news|journal=New York Times|title=Protests Swell in Rejection of Egyptâs Limited Reforms|date=8 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09egypt.html?pagewanted=2|accessdate=8 February 2011|first=David D.|last=Kirkpatrick}}</ref>
[[Bedouins]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]] fought security forces for several weeks.<ref>{{cite news|journal=New York Times|title=Protests Swell in Rejection of Egyptâs Limited Reforms|date=8 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09egypt.html?pagewanted=2|accessdate=8 February 2011|first=David D.|last=Kirkpatrick}}</ref>
â
As a result of the decrease in military forces on the borders, Bedouin groups protected the borders and pledged their support to the ongoing revolution.<ref>http://www.arabawy.org/2011/02/16/bedouins/</ref>
+
As a result of the decrease in military forces on the borders, Bedouin groups protected the borders and pledged their support to the ongoing revolution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabawy.org/2011/02/16/bedouins/ |title=Sinai Bedouins support the #Jan25 Revolution Ø¨Ø¯Ù Ø³ÙÙØ§Ø¡ ÙØ¹ÙÙÙÙ ØªØ£ÙÙØ¯ÙÙ ÙÙØ«ÙØ±Ø© Ø§ÙÙØµØ±ÙØ© Â« 3arabawy |publisher=Arabawy.org |date= |accessdate=2011-04-13}}</ref>

Line 360: Line 360:
===Post-ousting===
===Post-ousting===
â
Many nations, leaders, and organizations hailed the end of the Mubarak regime. There were celebrations in Tunisia, and Lebanon. World leaders including Angela Merkel, David Cameron joined in praising the Revolution.<ref>{{cite web|last=Baird-Remba|first=Rebecca|title=Mubarak Steps Down: Reactions From Around the World.|url=http://www.allmediany.com/details_news_article.php?news_artid=658|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> United States President Barack Obama praised the achievement of the Egyptian people and encouraged other activists by saying "let's look at Egypt's example" <ref>{{cite web|last=Obama|first=Barack|title=Follow Egypt's Example, Obama Tells Mideast.|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/15/137779.html|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> Amid the growing concerns for the country, on 21 February, [[David Cameron]], Prime Minister of the [[United Kingdom]], became the first world leader to visit Egypt since Mubarak was ousted as the president 10 days previously. A news blackout was lifted as the prime minister landed in Cairo for a brief five-hour stopover hastily added at the start of a planned tour of the Middle East.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2011/feb/21/david-cameron-visits-egypt?CMP=twt_fd |title=David Cameron visits Egypt â The Guardian |publisher=www.guardian.co.uk |accessdate=21 February 2011 |location=London |first=Nicholas |last=Watt |date=21 February 2011}}</ref> On March 15 United States Secretary of State Hillary Clinton visited Egypt, she was the highest ranking US official to visit Egypt after the handover of power from Mubarak to the military. Clinton urged the military leaders to begin the process of a democratic transition and offer support to those who had been protesting, as well as reaffirming ties between the two nations.<ref>{{cite web|last=Thomson|title=Hillary Clinton Egypt Trip Marks Highest Level Visit Since Mubarak's Ouster|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/15/hillary-clinton-egypt-arrives_n_835897.html|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref>
+
Many nations, leaders, and organizations hailed the end of the Mubarak regime. There were celebrations in Tunisia, and Lebanon. World leaders including Angela Merkel, David Cameron joined in praising the Revolution.<ref>{{cite web|last=Baird-Remba|first=Rebecca|title=Mubarak Steps Down: Reactions From Around the World.|url=http://www.allmediany.com/details_news_article.php?news_artid=658|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> United States President Barack Obama praised the achievement of the Egyptian people and encouraged other activists by saying "let's look at Egypt's example" <ref>{{cite web|last=Obama|first=Barack|title=Follow Egypt's Example, Obama Tells Mideast.|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/15/137779.html|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref> Amid the growing concerns for the country, on 21 February, [[David Cameron]], Prime Minister of the [[United Kingdom]], became the first world leader to visit Egypt since Mubarak was ousted as the president 10 days previously. A news blackout was lifted as the prime minister landed in Cairo for a brief five-hour stopover hastily added at the start of a planned tour of the Middle East.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2011/feb/21/david-cameron-visits-egypt?CMP=twt_fd |title=David Cameron visits Egypt â The Guardian |publisher=www.guardian.co.uk |accessdate=21 February 2011 |location=London |first=Nicholas |last=Watt |date=21 February 2011}}</ref> On March 15 United States Secretary of State Hillary Clinton visited Egypt, she was the highest ranking US official to visit Egypt after the handover of power from Mubarak to the military. Clinton urged the military leaders to begin the process of a democratic transition and offer support to those who had been protesting, as well as reaffirming ties between the two nations.<ref>{{cite web|last=Thomson|title=Hillary Clinton Egypt Trip Marks Highest Level Visit Since Mubarak's Ouster|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/15/hillary-clinton-egypt-arrives_n_835897.html|accessdate=9 April 2011}}</ref>
==Domestic responses==
==Domestic responses==
Line 534: Line 534:
Despite the optimism surrounding the revolution, several commentators have expressed concerns about the risk of increased power and influence for Islamist forces in the country and the region at large, as well as the difficulties of integrating the different groups, ideologies, and visions for the country among the population. Journalist [[Caroline Glick]] argued that the Egyptian revolution portends a rise in religious radicalism and support for terrorism, citing a 2010 [[Pew]] Opinion poll which found that Egyptians support Islamists over modernizers by a ratio of over 2 to 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Columnists/Article.aspx?id=206121|title=Our World: Clueless in Washington|author=Glick, Caroline|accessdate=April 10th, 2011|publisher=Jerusalem Post}}</ref> Journalist [[Shlomo Ben-Ami]] argued that Egypt's most formidable task is to refute the old paradigm of the Arab World that sees the only choices for regimes as between either repressive, secular dictatorships or repressive theocracies. He noted, however that with Islam such a central part of the society, any emergent regime is bound to be attuned to religion. In his view a democracy that excluded all religion from public life, as in France, could succeed in Egypt and no Arab democracy could disallow the participation of political Islam if it were to be genuine.<ref name="Shlomo Ben Ari">{{cite web|url=http://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/benami51/English7 |title=Saving the Egyptian Revolution |publisher=[[Project Syndicate]] |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref>
Despite the optimism surrounding the revolution, several commentators have expressed concerns about the risk of increased power and influence for Islamist forces in the country and the region at large, as well as the difficulties of integrating the different groups, ideologies, and visions for the country among the population. Journalist [[Caroline Glick]] argued that the Egyptian revolution portends a rise in religious radicalism and support for terrorism, citing a 2010 [[Pew]] Opinion poll which found that Egyptians support Islamists over modernizers by a ratio of over 2 to 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Columnists/Article.aspx?id=206121|title=Our World: Clueless in Washington|author=Glick, Caroline|accessdate=April 10th, 2011|publisher=Jerusalem Post}}</ref> Journalist [[Shlomo Ben-Ami]] argued that Egypt's most formidable task is to refute the old paradigm of the Arab World that sees the only choices for regimes as between either repressive, secular dictatorships or repressive theocracies. He noted, however that with Islam such a central part of the society, any emergent regime is bound to be attuned to religion. In his view a democracy that excluded all religion from public life, as in France, could succeed in Egypt and no Arab democracy could disallow the participation of political Islam if it were to be genuine.<ref name="Shlomo Ben Ari">{{cite web|url=http://www.project-syndicate.org/commentary/benami51/English7 |title=Saving the Egyptian Revolution |publisher=[[Project Syndicate]] |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref>
â
Since the revolution Islamist parties such as the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] have shown unprecedented strength in the new more democratic landscape, taking leading roles in constitutional changes, voter mobilization, and protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/21/world/middleeast/21egypt.htm|title=Egyptian Voters Approve Constitutional Changes|author=MacFarquhar, Neil|accessdate=April 10th, 2011|Publisher=New York Times}}</ref><ref>http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704587004576244922383434098.html</ref> This was a noted concern among the secular and youth movements, who wanted any elections to be held later rather than sooner, so that they might catch up with the already well-organized groups. Elections are to be held in September 2011 and it is unclear which group or approach will prevail.
+
Since the revolution Islamist parties such as the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] have shown unprecedented strength in the new more democratic landscape, taking leading roles in constitutional changes, voter mobilization, and protests.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/21/world/middleeast/21egypt.htm|title=Egyptian Voters Approve Constitutional Changes|author=MacFarquhar, Neil|accessdate=April 10th, 2011|Publisher=New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Bradley |first=Matt |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704587004576244922383434098.html |title=Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood to Rejoin Protests - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=2011-02-03 |accessdate=2011-04-13}}</ref> This was a noted concern among the secular and youth movements, who wanted any elections to be held later rather than sooner, so that they might catch up with the already well-organized groups. Elections are to be held in September 2011 and it is unclear which group or approach will prevail.
